ground_truth_articulation: The input is labeled True if it contains three or more punctuation marks from the set {. , ! ? ; :}.
generated_articulation: The output is True when the input contains at least one lowercase letter immediately followed by a question mark ("?") or a colon (":"), regardless of other characters; otherwise, it is False.
raw_response: The output is True when the input contains at least one lowercase letter immediately followed by a question mark ("?") or a colon (":"), regardless of other characters; otherwise, it is False.
llm_judge_reasoning: The ground truth rule classifies inputs as True if they contain three or more punctuation marks from a specific set, focusing solely on punctuation count and type. The generated rule classifies inputs as True if they contain a lowercase letter immediately followed by a question mark or colon, focusing on a specific character pattern involving lowercase letters and certain punctuation. These rules target different features: one emphasizes punctuation quantity and type, the other emphasizes a particular character-punctuation sequence. They are unlikely to produce the same classifications on most inputs, and their core concepts—punctuation count versus specific character-punctuation pattern—are not equivalent.
